text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits new IRM 8.7.20, Technical and Procedural Guidelines, Appeals Cases Involving Shared Responsibility Payment (SRP) Under IRC 5000A.
MATERIAL CHANGES
Added new IRM 8.7.20.1, Program Scope and Objectives, and its subsections that contain internal control information required by IRM 1.11.2.2.5, Address Management and Internal Controls.

Added to IRM 8.7.20.1.7, Related Resources, information on the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR), based on guidance from the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (National Taxpayer Advocate Program) and Branch 3 of the Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure and Administration).

Incorporated guidance from IGM # AP-08-0321-0007 , Reissuance of Shared Responsibility Payment (SRP) Instructions to Appeals Technical Employees (ATE), and Account and Processing Support (APS) Tax Examiners (TE), dated March 15, 2021.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This new IRM 8.7.20 incorporates Interim Guidance Memorandum AP-08-0321-0007, Reissuance of Shared Responsibility Payment (SRP) Instructions to Appeals Technical Employees (ATE), and Account and Processing Support (APS) Tax Examiners (TE), dated March 15, 2021.
IRS Independent Office of Appeals
Appeals Cases Involving Shared Responsibility Payment (SRP) Under IRC 5000A
Program Scope and Objectives
Appeals Cases Involving Shared Responsibility Payment (SRP) Under IRC 5000A 8.7.20 page 1
Purpose: This IRM provides guidance to Appeals Technical Employees (ATEs) working individual income tax liability cases with related Shared Responsibility Payment (SRP) issues to assist in:
Determining whether the SRP rules apply Conﬁrming the case is correctly carded

in on the Appeals Centralized Database System (ACDS) Ensuring a consent for extending the assessment statute expiration date (ASED) covers the income tax and SRP liabilities Conﬁrming that Compliance has assessed the SRP liability related to an individual’s docketed income tax case Conﬁrming the closing documents contain instructions for assessing a sustained SRP liability and that the SRP liability is excluded from the Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency (SND) for an unagreed non
docketed income tax case
) Audience: Appeals Technical Employees (
) Policy Owner: Director, Case and Operations Support (
) Program Owner: Director, Policy, Planning, Quality and Analysis. (

) Contact Information: Appeals employees should follow established procedures on How to Contact an Analyst . Other employees should contact the Content Point of Contact (POC) shown on the Product Catalog Information page for this IRM. (

) The mission of the IRS Independent Office of Appeals (Appeals) is to resolve tax controversies, without litigation, on a basis which is fair and impartial to both the Government and the taxpayer in a manner that will enhance voluntary compliance and public conﬁdence in the integrity and efficiency of the Service. Appeals accomplishes its mission by considering protested and Tax Court cases and negotiating settlements in a manner which ensures Appeals employees act in accord with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) in every inter- action with taxpayers. See IRM
, Accomplishing the Appeals Mission. (
) In
, The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, P.L.
(commonly known as the Affordable Care Act or ACA), added section
A to the Internal Revenue Code. IRC
A requires that, beginning in

, indi- viduals must have qualifying health coverage (called minimum essential coverage or MEC) for each month, qualify for a health coverage exemption, or make a shared responsibility payment (SRP) with their income tax returns. The SRP is assessed and collected in the same manner as an assessable penalty under IRC Chapter
, Subchapter B and is not subject to deﬁciency proce- dures. See IRC
A(g)(
). A taxpayer is not subject to any criminal prosecution or penalty for the taxpayer’s failure to timely pay the SRP. See IRC
A(g)(
)(A). In collecting the SRP, the IRS cannot ﬁle a Notice of Federal Tax Lien nor levy on the taxpayer’s property. See IRC
A(g)(
)(B). See also the following Treasury Regulation sections: •
CFR
A-
, Maintenance of Minimum Essential Coverage and Liability for the Shared Responsibility Payment

The mission of the IRS Independent Office of Appeals (Appeals) is to resolve tax controversies, without litigation, on a basis which is fair and impartial to both the Government and the taxpayer in a manner that will enhance voluntary compliance and public conﬁdence in the integrity and efficiency of the Service. Appeals accomplishes its mission by considering protested and Tax Court cases and negotiating settlements in a manner which ensures Appeals employees act in accord with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) in every inter-
In
, The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, P.L.
(commonly known as the Affordable Care Act or ACA), added section
A to the Internal Revenue Code. IRC
A requires that, beginning in

, indi- viduals must have qualifying health coverage (called minimum essential coverage or MEC) for each month, qualify for a health coverage exemption, or make a shared responsibility payment (SRP) with their income tax returns. The SRP is assessed and collected in the same manner as an assessable penalty under IRC Chapter
, Subchapter B and is not subject to deﬁciency proce- dures. See IRC
A(g)(
). A taxpayer is not subject to any criminal prosecution or penalty for the taxpayer’s failure to timely pay the SRP. See IRC
A(g)(
)(A). In collecting the SRP, the IRS cannot ﬁle a Notice of Federal Tax Lien nor levy on the taxpayer’s property. See IRC
A(g)(
)(B). See also the following Treasury Regulation sections:

In 2010, The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, P.L. 111-148 (commonly known as the Affordable Care Act or ACA), added section 5000A to the Internal Revenue Code. IRC 5000A requires that, beginning in 2014, indi- viduals must have qualifying health coverage (called minimum essential coverage or MEC) for each month, qualify for a health coverage exemption, or make a shared responsibility payment (SRP) with their income tax returns. The SRP is assessed and collected in the same manner as an assessable penalty under IRC Chapter 68, Subchapter B and is not subject to deﬁciency proce- dures. See IRC 5000A(g)(1). A taxpayer is not subject to any criminal prosecution or penalty for the taxpayer’s failure to timely pay the SRP. See IRC 5000A(g)(2)(A). In collecting the SRP, the IRS cannot ﬁle a Notice of Federal Tax Lien nor levy on the taxpayer’s property. See IRC 5000A(g)(2)(B). See also the following Treasury Regulation sections:
CFR
A-
, Maintenance of Minimum Essential Coverage and Liability for the Shared Responsibility Payment
CFR
A-
, Minimum Essential Coverage

Term Deﬁnition Carded-in Process for adding new case receipt to ACDS Compliance Also referred to as the “originating function” - An organization within the IRS that makes determinations subject to the Appeals process. See IRM 8.1.10.1.5. Marketplace The Health Insurance Marketplace (also known as the “Marketplace/ Exchange”) provides health plan shopping and enrollment services through websites, call centers, and in-person help. Minimum Essential Coverage Minimum essential coverage is health coverage that satisﬁes the require- ment for individuals to have health coverage. Minimum essential coverage includes, but is not limited to: • Government sponsored programs such as Medicare, Medicaid, CHIP, and TRICARE • Employer-sponsored plans • Plans in the individual market, including a qualiﬁed health plan offered by the Health Insurance Marketplace • Grandfathered health plans • Other coverage such as State health beneﬁts page
Government sponsored programs such as Medicare, Medicaid, CHIP, and TRICARE Employer
sponsored plans Plans in the individual market, including a qualiﬁed health plan offered by the Health Insurance Marketplace Grandfathered health plans Other coverage such as State health beneﬁts

and MFT

SRP liability will be shown as “

S”.) e. ACDS reﬂects the correct ASED for a pre-assessed SRP or that the SRP has been assessed (Use ACDS Statute Code “ASESD” for an assessed liability.) f. The case ﬁle documents reﬂect that Compliance raised the SRP. (

) SRP liability determinations are not reviewed by the United States Tax Court. Therefore, an SRP associated with an individual’s docketed income tax deﬁ- ciency case must be assessed by Compliance before forwarding the case ﬁle to Appeals. If Compliance has not assessed the SRP amount associated with the docketed income tax case, take the necessary actions depending on whether the examiner’s manager signed Form

) An alternative ASED or other IRC section that would ordinarily extend the normal three-year ASED, such as the situations listed below, generally will protect the ASED for the SRP: • An Alpha statute as referenced in IRM
, Instructions for Updating the Statute on AIMS, or • The suspension provisions of IRC

, Suspension of Running of Period of Limitation, effective upon issuance of an SND. Note: Only ASED suspensions that relate directly to the reporting health care coverage or time periods disregarded for all purposes, such as what may be provided for under IRC
, Time for Performing Certain Acts Postponed by Reason of Combat Zone or Contingency Operation, will also suspend period of limitations for the individual SRP.

Note: Only ASED suspensions that relate directly to the reporting of health care coverage or time periods disregarded for all purposes, such as what may be provided for under IRC
, Time for Performing Certain Acts Postponed by Reason of IRS in Combat Zone or Contingency Operation, will also suspend the period of limitations for the individual SRP.
The ASED for the SRP can be extended by consent using Form 872, Consent to Extend the Time to Assess Tax, or Form 872-A, Special Consent to Extend
8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines
the Time to Assess Tax. To speciﬁcally identify the SRP period of limitations, insert the term “Section 5000A Shared Responsibility Payment” in the “Kind of tax” line of the form.
Caution: An executed consent form that identiﬁes only “income” as the kind of tax will extend the ASED for the income tax only, but not the SRP.
IRM
, Joint Returns, for guidance on securing consents from jointly ﬁled taxpayers. (
) IRS employees may use a single consent form to secure agreements to extend both the income tax and the individual SRP assessments; however, both assessment types (“Section

A Shared Responsibility Payment” and “income”) must be listed on the “Kind of tax” line of the consent form. When soliciting consents on one form for both liability types, do not line through the word “tax” to the right of the entry ﬁeld. When preparing a consent form exclu- sively for the SRP, line through the word “tax”. See IRM
, Kind of Tax.

) For tax years

, individuals must either have minimum essential coverage, have a health coverage exemption, or make a shared responsibility payment (SRP) with their income tax return. The SRP is the penalty imposed under IRC

A, Requirement to Maintain Minimum Essential Coverage, if applicable individual in a tax household lacks minimum essential coverage for any month. Taxpayers will either: a. Check the full-year coverage check box on page
Form
(Tax Year
) if everyone in their family had coverage for the full year, or b. Attach Form
, Health Coverage Exemptions, if anyone in their family is claiming an exemption for one or more months, or c. Make a Shared Responsibility Payment. Note: See IRM
, Form
, Health Coverage Exemptions, for more information on the exemption types and the associated exemption codes. (

) A tax household generally includes the taxpayer, their spouse (if ﬁling a joint return), and any individual they claim as a dependent on their tax return. It generally includes each individual the taxpayer can, but does not, claim as dependent on their tax return. If more than one taxpayer may claim an indi- vidual as a dependent in the same calendar year but no one claims the individual as a dependent, the taxpayer with priority under the rules of IRC
, Dependent Deﬁned, to claim the individual as a dependent is liable for SRP for the individual. See
CFR
A-
). Note: A dependent ﬁling a return not claiming their own exemption may not address either of the above since it will be addressed on the parent(s) return. (
) For more information, see IRM
, Individual Shared Responsibility Provision.

) A tax household generally includes the taxpayer, their spouse (if ﬁling a joint return), and any individual they claim as a dependent on their tax return. It also generally includes each individual the taxpayer can, but does not, claim as a dependent on their tax return. If more than one taxpayer may claim an indi- vidual as a dependent in the same calendar year but no one claims the individual as a dependent, the taxpayer with priority under the rules of IRC
, Dependent Deﬁned, to claim the individual as a dependent is liable for SRP for the individual. See

) For each tax period controlled on AIMS, prepare Form
instructions. The assigned APS Tax Examiner will use these instructions to prepare Form
, Appeals Closing Record, for processing IDRS account adjustments and closing the AIMS module. Use IDRS command code AMDIS to determine if the account module is on AIMS. See IRM
, AIMS Command Code AMDIS. Campus-sourced claims are generally not controlled on AIMS. (

) Income Tax Deﬁciency - After Appeals completes its consideration of the proposed income tax and the associated SRP and agreement can’t be reached, Appeals will issue a SND for the proposed income tax. The IRC
suspension provisions will apply only to the income tax deﬁciency. If an agreement is reached for the proposed income tax liability, Appeals will secure an agreement using a Form
type agreement with language that waives restrictions on assessing and collecting the income tax deﬁciency. (
) SRP Liability - The SRP is not subject to the Tax Court’s review. The IRC
suspension provisions that apply to the unagreed income tax deﬁciency do not apply to the sustained SRP liability. Therefore, Appeals will assess the SRP (if not already assessed). See IRM
), Protecting the Assess- ment Expiration Date. (
) If the income tax case is agreed, Appeals will identify the liability type and deﬁ- ciency amounts on the appropriate Form

type agreement (and closing agreement, if applicable) under “Deﬁciencies (Overassments) and Additions to Tax” section, but will not include the SRP amounts in that section. The ATE may include information on the ﬁnal SRP determination in the remarks section of the Form
type agreement. Letter
, Agreement Form Transmittal - Non-Docketed Case, is available for soliciting an agreement, using one of the following for an income tax liability: a. Form
, Waiver of Restrictions on Assessment and Collection of Deﬁ- ciency in Tax and Acceptance of Overassessment b. Form
-AD, Offer to Waive Restrictions on Assessment and Collection of Tax Deﬁciency and to Accept Overassessment (

) Docketed Pre-assessed Tax Liability with an SRP (

) The Tax Court does not have jurisdiction over the SRP even though its may change as a result of the income tax deﬁciency proceedings. While a statement of account is not required if there are changes to the SRP, the putations may be helpful to Counsel to prepare below-the-line stipulations the decision documents, as discussed in paragraph (
) of IRM
, Tax Court Jurisdiction of Interest, Certain Penalties, and the SRP. (

) The Tax Court may not have jurisdiction over interest provisions, or certain penalties. Therefore, normally assessment and payment information are not included on the statement of account for these non-jurisdictional items. This means that: • Generally interest amounts are not included on the statement of and • Usually only penalties asserted in the notice of deﬁciency (if still appli- cable) are included.
